Great question indeed. Lots of human experiences have been lost through countless time and space dimensions. An ordinary Aztec man’s one day in June 24th when he was 22 years old was never written anywhere, and we won’t likely ever know what it was like. The rest of history can be thought of as such. Even contemporary history has many fuzzy parts, yet alone the classic history! However it’s abnormal to record every breath of all human at all the places all the time, unless you’re the Big Brother of an Orwellian Thought Police. History is a synthesis of facts, hearsay evidence, claims, myths, frauds and even rumors. And in our age of IT revolution and burst of information load, it’s way too easy to manipulate history and keep certain facts obscure, and eventually hidden. One great example is the atrocities and war crimes conducted by the Allies like massacres by Communist Russia or even the universally well-known Hiroshima & Nagasaki A-bombs that have been manipulated as such to represent that such carnage was the “necessary evil”, but it wasn’t. Yet because scant evidence survives about it, and even such evidence are ignored, unpublished, unspoken of and un-debated, they fall out of “mainstream” and gradually fade away, while alternative interpretations with specific sponsors who are ready to buy many thousands of copies of books to make it a bestseller and hence, make the public read it; will survive and ultimately be held as the true account of what happened. Eventually, the true versions sometimes end up in the trash bin of history, and cleared away from the collective memory of the society. And it’s no wonder years later so many people deny such things as Allies war crimes’ very existence, or happening at all!
